In contrast, Pieris species typically have a single (males) or a pair (females) of blackish post-discal spots on the forewings, and no trace of any spot or band on the hindwings. Pieris is a genus of seven species of shrubs in the family Ericaceae, native to mountain regions of eastern and southern Asia, eastern North America, and Cuba. These broad-leaved evergreen shrubs can grow up to 1-3 meters tall and have leaves that are spirally arranged and appear to be in whorls at the end of each shoot with bare stretches of shoot below. The leaves are lanceolate-ovate, 2-long and 1.0- broad, leathery textured, and have an entire or serrated margin. The young leaves in spring are often brightly colored. The flowers are bell-shaped, 5-long, white or pink, and arranged in racemes 5-long. The fruit is a woody capsule that splits into five sections to release the numerous small seeds.

These ferns are closely related to Polypodium, and the species were formerly included in that genus. Pieris floribunda is a North American species of broadleaf evergreen shrub, commonly known as mountain fetterbush or mountain andromeda. All parts of Pieris floribunda are poisonous if ingested, making it a rare plant to find in landscapes due to the difficulty in propagating it and its tendency not to adapt well to cultivation. However, some specialty and native plant nurseries sell it. In landscapes, it should be grown in full to part shade, out of windy locations, and have a good quality soil with lots of organic matter that is acidic with a pH of 4.5 to 6.5.

The whites or garden whites are a widespread and almost cosmopolitan genus of butterflies in the family Pieridae, with the highest species diversity found in the Palearctic region. Many species of this genus have caterpillars that feed on cabbage and other members of the Brassicaceae, and the chemical basis of this association has been studied for over 100 years. Pieris caterpillars are able to detoxify these chemicals, and have become so specialized that they will only eat plants that contain glucosinolates. The females of the genus also check for the presence of glucosinolates before laying eggs on a plant. In conclusion, Sinopieris and Pieris are two distinct genera of butterflies and shrubs, respectively, with distinct characteristics and distributions.
